questions.text: 60% of the total body water in is which of the following compartments?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) intracellular

Two-thirds of the total body water is in the ICF.

questions.text: Which of the following are best suited to measure the intracellular fluid volume?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Heavy water and inulin

Measurement of ICF is indirect. ICF = TBW – ECF. Heavy water is most used for measurement of total body eater and Inulin is the most accurate for measurement of ECF volume. A combination of heavy water and inulin is best suited for measurement of ICF.

Radioactive sodium is used for ECF measurement.

Radioactive iodine labelled albumin is used for measurement of plasma volume.

questions.text: A 70-year old man has congestive cardiac failure. His cardiac output is 4L/min, bp is 110/80 mm Hg and heart rate is 90/minute. Further tests reveal that his right atrial pressure is 10 mm Hg. Which of the following will be expected to increase in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increase in RAP to 10 mm Hg decreases the venous return to the heart and therefore, increase the vena cava hydrostatic pressure. This in turn increases the tissue capillary hydrostatic pressure, especially in the capillaries of the lower limb (if patient is ambulant), leading to pedal edema.

questions.text: The equation which is used to calculate the magnitude of the equilibrium potential of a freely diffusible ion is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Donnan and Gibbs showed that in the presence of a non diffusible ion, the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal. This is the Gibbs Donnan Equation.

If a membrane is freely permeable to an ion, magnitude of potential difference for that ion at equilibrium (equilibrium potential or Nernst potential) can be calcuklated by the Nernst Equation.

Goldmann Hodgkin Katz equation is used to calculate the RMP.

Henderson Hasselbach equation is used to calculate the pH of a buffer solution containing given concentrations of an acid and its conjugate base.

questions.text: Gibbs- Donnan equilibrium is based on which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Intracellular proteins

Donnan and Gibbs showed that in the presence of a non-diffusible ion (proteins), the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that equilibrium, their concentration ratios are equal:

This is the Gibbs- Donnan equation. It is applicable for any pair of cations and anions of the same valence.

questions.text: If alveolar surface area is decreased by 50% and pulmonary fibrosis leads to doubling of diffusion distance, how will the diffusion of O2 be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) decreases by 75%

Diffusion of gases across the respiratory membrane follows the Fick’s law of diffusion.

Net transport

= - (diffusion coefficient) (surface area) (concentration gradient)/ (thickness of membrane)

Transport is directly proportional to surface area and inverse to the thickness of membrane. If the surface area is decreased to half and thickness of membrane is doubled, transport is decreases to one-fourth or in other words, decreases by 75%.

questions.text: Which of the following has similar values for both ICF and ISF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 
Total osmolality
Colloid osmotic pressure is determine by proteins, which are much higher in the ICF than ISF. Colloid osmotic pressure is higher in ICF.
Potassium is higher in ICF.
Sodium is higher in ISF.

questions.text: Hypertonic 3% saline contains how much of Na+ in meq/l?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
513
1 equivalent of a substance = 1 mole of that substance/ (No. of metal ions) X (valence)
For NaCl, 1 equivalent = 1 mole
3% NaCl = 3 gm of NaCl in 100mL = 30 gm of NaCl in 1000mL
58.5 gm of NaCl = 1 mole of NaCl
30 gm of NaCl = 30/58.5 mole = 0.513 mole = 513 millimole = 513 milliequivalent

choices.text: Can be blocked by specific transporters

questions.text: Simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion share which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion are examples of passive transport and therefore, do not require energy for transport.

questions.text: Most important buffer in the interstitial fluid is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) bicarbonate

The principal buffer in the interstitial fluid is bicarbonate.

choices.text: The term “homeostasis” describes the maintenance of nearly constant conditions in the body
Disease is generally considered to be a state of disrupted homeostasis
Body’s compensatory mechanisms often lead to small deviations from the normal range in some of the body’s functions
In most diseases, homeostatic mechanisms are no longer operating.

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) In most diseases, homeostatic mechanisms are no longer operating

The term “homeostasis” refers to the maintenance of nearly constant conditions in the internal environment (“milieu interieur”). Even in disease, homeostatic compensatory mechanisms continue to operate in an attempt to sustain bodily functions.

questions.text: Excess blood is transfused into a patient whose mean arterial pressure increases from 100 to 125 mm Hg. After correction, the patient’s blood pressure is 105 mm Hg. What is the “gain”?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) -4

Gain = Correction / error

Since the MAP lowers from 125 to 105 mm Hg, the correction is -20mm Hg. Here the minus sign does not have a mathematical significance. It simple means that the corrected blood pressure is lower.

The error is +5 mm Hg. The plus sign here indicates that the corrected blood pressure is higher than the normal MAP.

Gain = -20/+4 = -4

choices.text: Most control systems in the body act by negative feedback
Generation of nerve action potentials involves positive feedback
Feed- forward is important in regulating motor activity

questions.text: Which statement about feedback control systems is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Positive feedback systems are stabilizing.

Most control systems in the body act by negative feedback mechanisms and these are stabilizing. They help maintain homeostasis.

questions.text: All of the following for tight junctions except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) connexins

Connexins form “gap junctions”.

choices.text: Gap junctions form a cytoplasmic “tunnel” for diffusion of small molecules (<1000 Da) between two neighbouring cells
Gap junctions are formed by proteins called connexons
Connexons in the membrane of one cell are lined up with connexons of a neighbouring cell to form dodecameric gap junctions

questions.text: All of the following are true about gap junctions except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Gap junctions form chemical synapses

Gap junctions form electrical synapses. They for a low resistance path for bi-directional movement of ions, molecules, sugars and amino acids less than 1000 Daltons.

questions.text: All of the following are present on the alpha subunit of the sodium potassium ATPase pump except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) glycosylation site

Glycosylation site is on the beta subunit.

choices.text: Includes phagocytosis and pinocytosis, but not clathrin- mediated or caveolae dependent uptake of extracellular contents
Refers to merging of an intracellular vesicle with the plasma membrane to deliver vesicular contents to the ECF
Refers to the invagination of the cell membrane to uptake extracellular contents into the cell
Refers vesicular trafficking between golgi apparatus

questions.text: Which of the following is true about endocytosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Refers to the invagination of the cell membrane to uptake extracellular contents into the cell. It includes phagocytosis (“cell eating”) and pinocytosis (“cell drinking”), clathrin- mediated endocytosis and caveolae dependent uptake of extracellular contents.

questions.text: Sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

NIS (secondary active co-transport) is present in

  • Thyroid cells
  • Salivary glands
  • Stomach
  • Intestinal epithelial cells (apical membrane)
  • Gestational breast

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms for transport across the luminal cell membrane of an enterocyte is present in newborns and infants but not in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intestinal absorption of immunoglobulins (in colostrum) during early infancy occurs by endocytosis. This ability to absorb large molecules by endocytosis occurs during the first several months of life but is lost thereafter. Simple diffusion, facilitated diffusion, primary and secondary active transports are all normal processes in enterocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following ions is higher in the ICF?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) K+

choices.text: Negative feedback system with error of zero
Negative feedback system with correction of zero
Negative feedback system with gain of zero
There is no such thing as infinite gain in a feedback system

questions.text: Which of the following describes infinite feedback gain principle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Negative feedback system with error of zero

For a negative feedback system,

Gain = correction/ error

If error is zero, the gain is infinite.

The control of arterial pressure by the renal- body fluid mechanism, where the arterial pressure always exactly comes back to equilibrium point, makes it an example of infinite feedback gain principle.

choices.text: Safety factor due to low tissue compliance in the negative pressure range is 3 mm Hg
Safety factor due to increased lymph flow is 7 mm Hg
Safety factor due to washout of proteins from the interstitial spaces is 7 mm Hg
Total safety factor of 17 mm Hg implies that the edema results when the capillary hydrostatic pressure is 17 mm Hg

questions.text: All of the following are true about the safety factor against edema except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Total safety factor of 17 mm Hg implies that the edema results when the capillary hydrostatic pressure is 17 mm Hg.

Total safety factor against edema is 17 mm Hg. This implies that capillary pressure in a peripheral tissue must theoretically rise by 17 mm Hg before marked edema occurs. The three factors which contribute to safety factor of 17 mm Hg are

  1. Low tissue compliance in the negative pressure range which contributes about 3 mm Hg
  2. Increased lymph flow which contributes about 7 mm Hg
  3. Washout of proteins from the interstitial spaces by the increased lymph flow which contributes approximately 7 mm Hg

questions.text: The most important factor which determines the movement of a permeant substance across the cell membrane is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Diffusion coefficient of a substance is determined mainly by the lipid solubility of that substance.

questions.text: In an ideal solution, which of the following is correct? (P is osmotic pressure, n is number of particles, R is gas constant, T is absolute temperature, V is volume)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

P = nRT/V. If T is constant, osmotic pressure is proportional to the number of particles in solution per unit volume of the solution.

questions.text:
The following graph shows the transport kinetics of a solute transferred across cell membrane

What is the  likely   nature  of the  solute    :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Since carrier proteins tend to get saturated all carrier mediated transports will have a transport maxima. Glucose is transported by facilitated diffusion which is carrier mediated. Therefore, transport of glucose will show a transport maxima.

questions.text: The blood-cytoplasm gradient generated by pump or leak systems is maximum for which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The blood: cytoplasm ratio for Na+ is 12:1, for K+ it is 1:35, for H+ it is 1:2.5, for Ca++ it is 18,000:1.

questions.text: In a clinical study to study the actions of an unknown test solution on RBC volume, 1 mL of heparinized blood is added into 100mL of test solution and mixed. Results show that the RBCs placed into the test solution immediately sell and burst. Into which of the following test solutions were the RBCs placed (intracellular osmolality is 280mosmol/L)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 140mmol of glucose

If the RBCs swell and burst then they must have been added to a hypotonic solution. 140mmol of glucose is equal to 140mosmol of glucose, which is hypotonic.

choices.text: Loss of 1L of blood in a road traffic accident

questions.text:
Given below is a Darrow- Yannet diagram. The normal state (orange and yellow) is superimposed on the abnormal state (dashed lines) to illustrate the shifts in volume (width of rectangle) and total osmolality (height of rectangles) of the extracellular and intracellular fluid compartments.

Which of the following represents the changes (after osmotic equilibrium)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Loss of 1L of blood in a road traffic accident

Loss of 1L of blood is equivalent to loss of iso-osmotic fluid. It will produce a decrease in ECF volume with no change in osmolality.

questions.text: Cholera toxin acts by disrupting which of the following in the intestinal epithelial cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) zonula occludens

Vibrio cholerae releases cholera toxin (CT) and zona occludens toxin (ZOT). CT binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the apical surface. The massive secretion of salt and water in cholera-induced diarrhoea involves binding of cholera toxin (CT) to ganglioside GM1 in the apical membrane of intestinal epithelial cells, translocation of the enzymatically active A1-peptide across the membrane, and subsequent activation of adenylate cyclase located on the cytoplasmic surface of the basolateral membrane.

questions.text:
Using the following data, calculate the filtration coefficient for the capillary bed.

Plasma colloid osmotic pressure = 30 mm Hg

Capillary hydrostatic pressure = 40 mm Hg

Interstitial colloid osmotic pressure = 5 mm Hg

Interstitial hydrostatic pressure = 5 mm Hg

Rate of tissue fluid formation = 150mL/min
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 15mL/ min/ mm Hg

Rate of tissue fluid formation = Filtration coefficient X (Pc – πc – Pi + πi)

150mL/ min = Filtration coefficient X (40 – 30 – 5 + 5)mm Hg

Filtration coefficient = 150/10 = 15mL/ min/ mm Hg

questions.text: If the concentration of Na+ in ECF is 150 meq/L, and 15 meq/L in ICF, Calculate the equilibrium potential of Na+?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) +60mV

Equilibrium potential for sodium can be measured by the Nernst equation.

ENa+ (mV) = 61 log 150/15 = 61 log10 = 61mV

questions.text: Which of the following nerve fibres is the least susceptible to local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A gamma nerve fibres are the most susceptible to local anesthetics and C are the least susceptible.

questions.text: Increase in which of the following ion in the ECF has the maximum effect on neuronal excitability?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Explanation- with increase in K+ concentration in ECF, the gradient for potassium will decrease. This causes less K+ to diffuse out from the cell. Increase in positive charge inside the cells causes the membrane potential to become less negative resulting in depolarization and increase in excitability. One of the common symptoms of hyperkalemia is arrythmias.

questions.text: The equilibrium potential for potassium is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The equilibrium potential or Nernst potential for potassium is -90mV.

questions.text:
The RMP of a cell is -70mV. The equilibrium potentials for important ions under normal physiologic conditions are as follows:-

ECa = +125mV

ENa = +60mv

EMg = 0mV

ECl = -70mV

EK = -90mV

If physiologic conditions are maintained which of the following is likely to flow out of the cells after opening their respective ion channels.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) potassium

Potassium is higher intracellularly. If potassium channels open and the membrane permeability for potassium increases, potassium will move out of the cell till the cell reaches the equilibrium potential of potassium.

questions.text: Which ion has the lowest electrochemical driving force in a neuron with RMP of -65mV?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Chloride

  • When an ion is not at its equilibrium, an electrochemical driving force (VDF) acts on the ion, causing the net movement of the ion across the membrane down its own electrochemical gradient. The driving force is quantified by the difference between the membrane potential and the ion equilibrium potential VDF = Vm − Veq.

Driving force = RMP – equilibrium potential

ECl- = -70mV

Driving force for Cl- = -65 – (-70) = -5mV

Driving force for sodium = -65 – (+61) = - 126mV

Driving force for calcium = -65 – (+125) = -187 mV

Driving force for magnesium = -65 – (0) = -65mV

Minus sign means a net inward current or inward flux of the ion.

Plus sign means a net outward current or outward flux of the ion. Positive driving force yields a positive outward current according to Ohm’s law (V = I X R) 

On a lighter note,

questions.text: Membrane of a cell is freely permeable to three ion X, Y and Z. The respective equilibrium potentials of X and Y are -30mV and -40mV. The resting membrane potential of the cell is -90 mV. What will happen to the membrane potential if a drug is infused which can block the permeability of Z?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Depolarization

The equilibrium potential of Z is -20 mV. By using a drug which blocks Z, the RMP of the cell will be -70 mV or the cell will be depolarized.

questions.text: The RMP of a large, myelinated nerve fibre is primarily dependent on the concentration gradient of which of the following ions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) K+

At rest, the cell membrane is most permeable to potassium. Efflux of potassium through “leak” channels causes the inside of cells to become more negative with respect to outside. This negative potential inside the cells with respect to outside is k/a the resting membrane potential.

questions.text: Identify the ions A and B respectively from the conductance graph of a neuron shown below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text:
Neurophysiologists are studying the recordings of the membrane potential from a giant squid axon. A portion of their recordings is shown.

Which point on the action potential coincides with maximum membrane conductance for sodium?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Point 3

questions.text: IPSP can be produced which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Increase in chloride influx causes the inside of the cell to become more negative, leading to hyperpolarization or IPSP.

Increasing sodium and calcium influx would result in a depolarization or EPSP.

Potassium influx through potassium channels is not a possibility since potassium is in a lower concentration outside the cells.

questions.text: If the duration of the absolute refractory period in a large diameter, myelinated nerve fiber is 1/2500 second, what is the maximum number of impulses that can be transmitted by this nerve fibre in one second?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 2500

The maximum number of action potentials that can be transmitted by a nerve fibre is 1/duration of absolute refractory period in seconds. If duration of absolute refractory period is 1/2500 second, then the maximum number of impulses transmitted by this nerve in one second is 2500.

choices.text: Entry of Na+ during the depolarization phase causes opening of more voltage-gated Na+ channels and further depolarization, setting up a positive feedback loop.
During the rapid upstroke phase the membrane potential moves toward the equilibrium potential for Na+ (+60 mV).
The Na+ channels rapidly enter a closed state called the inactivated state
Efflux of K+ through slow voltage-gated K+ channels bring the action potential to an end and cause closure of their gates through a positive feedback process.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT TRUE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Entry of Na+ during the depolarization phase causes opening of more voltage-gated Na+ channels and further depolarization, setting up a positive feedback loop. During the rapid upstroke phase the membrane potential moves toward the equilibrium potential for Na+ (+60 mV) but does not reach it during the action potential primarily because the increase in Na+ conductance is short-lived. The Na+ channels rapidly enter a closed state called the inactivated state and remain in this state for a few milliseconds before returning to the resting state, when they again can be activated. The opening of voltage-gated K+ channels is slower and more prolonged than the opening of the Na+ channels, and consequently, the increase in K+ conductance comes after the increase in Na+ conductance. The net movement of positive charge out of the cell due to K+ efflux at this time helps complete the process of repolarization. The slow return of the K+ channels to the closed state also explains the afterhyperpolarization, followed by a return to the resting membrane potential. Thus, efflux of K+ through voltage-gated K+ channels bring the action potential to an end and cause closure of their gates through a negative feedback process.

questions.text: Four hypothetical nerve fibres are shown. Axons A and B are myelinated whereas axons C and D are unmyelinated. Which axon is likely to have the maximum conduction velocity for an action potential?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The velocity of conduction of action potential is directly proportional to the diameter of the axon. More the diameter, more is the conduction velocity.

Myelination increases the velocity of conduction of a nerve impulse by several orders of magnitude more compared with the effect of an increase in axon diameter, which means that a large, myelinated axon has the highest velocity of conduction. Therefore, even though axon D has the largest diameter, myelinated axon B can conduct an action potential at a much greater velocity.

questions.text: Which part of the neuron has the highest concentration of sodium channels per unit area?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) nodes of Ranvier

Maximum number of sodium channels per unit area are at the nodes of ranvier (2000 channels per square micrometer). Least are at on the surface of myelin.

questions.text: Sensory (afferent) fibres from the muscle spindle are which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Ia and II

The sensory fibres from the muscle spindle are types Ia and II. Sensory or afferent fibres from the golgi tendon organ are type Ib.

questions.text: A neurotransmitter activates its receptor on an ion channel of a neuron. Once the channel is open, ions move through the channel down their respective electrochemical gradients. Which of the following best describes the type of channel and mechanism of ion transport?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Ligand- gated channel and simple diffusion

A neurotransmitter is considered a ligand. When the neurotransmitter binds to its receptor on an ion channel, causing the channel to open, the channel is said to be a ligand- gated. Voltage- gated channels open in response to changes in membrane potential. The mechanism of transport through ion channels is by simple diffusion. Facilitated diffusion, primary active transport, secondary active transport require special transport proteins rather than channels in the membrane.

questions.text: Site of generation of an action potential in a spinal motor neuron is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Initial segment

The site of generation of an action potential in a spinal motor neuron is the initial segment. Site of generation of an action potential in a sensory neuron is the initial or first node of ranvier.

choices.text: It can be fast or slow
It is towards the “plus” end of microtubules
The molecular motors used are kinesin and myosin V
Neurotropic viruses are transported by this mechanism

questions.text: All of the following are features of anterograde axoplasmic transport except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Neurotropic viruses are transported by this mechanism

Neurotropic viruses are transported in a retrograde fashion towards the central nervous system.

questions.text: Fastest velocity of conduction of nerve impulse is seen in nerve fibres with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) High membrane resistance, low capacitance

Fastest velocity of conduction of nerve impulse is seen in large diameter, myelinated nerve fibres. Large diameter, myelinated nerve fibres have low axoplasmic resistance, high membrane resistance, low membrane capacitance.
